```json
{
  "Q1": "What forms can neem urea coating be found in?",
  "A1": "Neem urea coating can be found in either liquid form or powdered form.",
  "Q2": "What are the properties of neem urea coating?",
  "A2": "Neem urea coating has anti-feedant and pest growth regulator properties.",
  "Q3": "What is neem cake used for in agriculture?",
  "A3": "Neem cake is used as an organic fertilizer in agriculture to improve soil fertility and promote plant growth.",
  "Q4": "What are the benefits of using neem as manure?",
  "A4": "Neem manure is environmental friendly and helps increase the nitrogen and phosphorous content in the soil.",
  "Q5": "What is neem soil conditioner used for?",
  "A5": "Neem soil conditioner is used to improve soil's physical condition, usually its fertility, and enhance soil quality parameters.",
  "Q6": "How is neem soil conditioner applied?",
  "A6": "Neem soil conditioner can be applied during sowing of seeds or spread and raked over the field, followed by proper irrigation.",
  "Q7": "What is the advantage of using neem-based pesticides?",
  "A7": "Neem-based pesticides do not leave any toxic residue on plants and do not destroy natural predators and parasites of pests.",
  "Q8": "How does neem oil reduce pest population?",
  "A8": "Neem oil reduces pest population by not allowing the female to deposit eggs on stored grains or feed on them, acting as an oviposition deterrent.",
  "Q9": "What is the effect of neem products on earthworms?",
  "A9": "Neem products have a positive and significant effect on mortality, growth, and reproduction of earthworms.",
  "Q10": "What are the benefits of using neem-based products in agriculture?",
  "A10": "Neem-based products are eco-friendly, superior in quality, and help overcome ecological and health threats imposed by chemical pesticides, making them a boon for organic agriculture."
}
```

```json
  "Q1": "How can gunny bags be treated to store grains?",
  "A1": "Gunny bags should be dipped in 10% neem kernel solution for 15 min, dried in shade, and used for storing grains.",
  
  "Q2": "What is the advantage of using neem oil for stored grain pests?",
  "A2": "Neem oil is easier to use than leaves and can be used at a concentration of 1% by weight of the grains.",
  
  "Q3": "What is the active ingredient of the neem plant?",
  "A3": "The active ingredient of the neem plant is more in seed and kernel, specifically azadirachtin.",
  
  "Q4": "What are the benefits of neem fumigation?",
  "A4": "Neem fumigation is non-toxic, eco-friendly, does not contaminate the environment, and pests do not develop resistance to it.",
  
  "Q5": "How can neem products be used to store grains and pulses?",

  "Q8": "How can new gunny bags be treated for storing grains?",

  "Q9": "What is the role of neem in Integrated Pest Management (IPM)?",

  "Q10": "Where can experiences with Indian farming be shared?",
```

```json
{
  "Q1": "What is the purpose of the contributions received from donors?",
  "A1": "The contributions will be utilized to carry out/enhance/augment various research and farmers outreach activities as per the provisions of MoU/MoA/LoI of ICAR and the Contributor(s); and Government of India guidelines.",
  
  "Q2": "What are the eligible areas for CSR funding as per the Ministry of Corporate Affairs?",
  "A2": "Contribution to incubators funded by Central Government or State Government, and contributions to public funded Universities, Indian Institute of Technology (IITs), National Laboratories and Autonomous Bodies are eligible for CSR funding.",
  
  "Q3": "What are the guidelines that ICAR shall follow for CSR?",
  "A3": "ICAR shall follow the provisions of the CSR Rules laid down by the Ministry of Corporate Affairs, Government of India from time to time under the Companies Act, 2013 and its amendments.",
  
  "Q4": "Can contributors prescribe specific deliverables or impose their area of interest in exchange for contributions?",
  "A4": "No, contributions under CSR reflect voluntary contribution and contributor(s) cannot prescribe any particular deliverable benefit or item or impose their area of interest in exchange from ICAR for contributions.",
  
  "Q5": "What are the admissible activities under CSR as per Schedule VII of the Companies Act, 2013?",
  "A5": "The Schedule provides an umbrella of activities that can be taken up through CSR, including Scientific Research and agricultural extension.",
  
  "Q6": "Are there any tax exemptions for CSR activities related to Scientific Research and agricultural extension?",
  "A6": "Yes, these activities enjoy exemptions under the Income Tax rules.",
  
  "Q7": "What are some examples of R&D activities that can be supported under CSR?",
  "A7": "Examples include research and agricultural extension/education funding, capacity building and income augmentation through skilling of farmers and scientists, seed and planting materials research, and R&D for diversification of farm activities.",
  
  "Q8": "Can CSR activities focus on livelihood improvement and poverty eradication?",
  "A8": "Yes, CSR activities can focus on livelihood improvement and poverty eradication, such as research and agricultural extension/education funding that helps in enhancing availability, access, and affordability of food items.",
  
  "Q9": "Are there any specific areas that ICAR can consider under CSR activities?",
  "A9": "Yes, ICAR can consider areas such as eradicating extreme hunger and poverty, capacity building and income augmentation, seed and planting materials research, and livelihood projects creating rainwater harvesting structures and maintenance of water.",
  
  "Q10": "What is the overall goal of CSR activities in the context of ICAR?",
  "A10": "The overall goal is to promote Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through research and development activities in science, technology, engineering, and medicine, with a focus on agricultural extension and livelihood improvement."
}
```

```json
{
  "Q1": "What are millets and why are they important?",
  "A1": "Millets are a group of small-seeded grasses that are highly tolerant to environmental stresses and have high physiological efficiency, making them an important food security crop in many parts of the world.",
  
  "Q2": "What are the key adaptive traits of millets that make them climate-resilient?",
  "A2": "Millets have a short growing season, deep root system, and ability to tolerate high temperatures and drought conditions, making them well-suited for climate resilience.",
  
  "Q3": "What is the significance of millets in terms of their physiological and anatomical makeup?",
  "A3": "The physiological and anatomical makeup of millets makes them superior to other crops in terms of their ability to harness available resources like light, water, and other inputs, and they have evolved to be more drought-tolerant and sustainable.",
  
  "Q4": "What are some examples of millet crops?",
  "A4": "Examples of millet crops include sorghum (jowar), pearl millet (bajra), finger millet (ragi), foxtail millet (kangani), barnyard millet (sanwa), proso millet (chenna), little millet (kutki), and kodo millet (kodo).",
  
  "Q5": "What are the nutritional benefits of millets?",
  "A5": "Millets are considered as nutri-cereals due to their abundant nutritional benefits, including food and fodder value, ecological benefits, and reduced reliance on chemical fertilizers.",
  
  "Q6": "How do millets compare to other cereals in terms of water usage?",
  "A6": "Millets have a low water footprint and can grow under drought conditions, even in very low rainfall regimes, making them more water-efficient than other cereals like wheat, rice, or corn.",
  
  "Q7": "What makes millets 'climate-smart' crops?",
  "A7": "Millets are considered climate-smart crops due to their ability to cope with changing climate, sustain productivity, and exhibit resilience to abiotic stresses, making them a promising solution for farmers in the face of climate vulnerabilities.",
  
  "Q8": "How do millets handle drought and high temperatures?",
  "A8": "Millets are known for their hardiness and can withstand prolonged periods of drought and high temperatures, still yielding grains and fodder.",
  
  "Q9": "What is the C4 photosynthetic system and how does it benefit millets?",
  "A9": "The C4 photosynthetic system operating in millet crops allows them to harness available resources more efficiently and makes them less affected by increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, with no or negligible greenhouse gas emissions.",
  
  "Q10": "Why is it important to understand the physiological traits and anatomical makeup of millets?",
  "A10": "Understanding the physiological traits and anatomical makeup of millets is necessary to unlock their full potential and to develop superior and high-yielding varieties that can compete with other major cereals."
}
```

```json
{
  "Q1": "What is the recommended time for nursery sowing of rice?",
  "A1": "Nursery sowing of rice may be completed from 20th May to first week of June.",
  
  "Q2": "What are the recommended varieties of rice for timely sown rice?",
  "A2": "High yielding varieties HPR 1068, HPR 2143, RP 2421, HPR 2720, HPR 2880, and university recommended/tested rice hybrids like Arize 6129, Arize Swift, Arize Swift Gold, BS 10008 etc.",
  
  "Q3": "What is the recommended fertilizer dose for transplanted rice crop?",
  "A3": "NPK @ 90:40:40 with 50% N and entire dose of P & K at the time of transplanting and remaining N in two equal doses at 3 and 6 weeks after transplanting.",
  
  "Q4": "How can zinc deficiency be managed in rice crop?",
  "A4": "Apply 60 kg of zinc sulphate heptahydrate (21%) or 40 kg zinc sulphate monohydrate (33%) per hectare at puddling.",
  
  "Q5": "What is the recommended herbicide for weed management in transplanted rice?",
  "A5": "Butachlor 5 G @ 30 kg/ha or broadcast Butachlor 50EC @ 3L after mixing within 72 hrs of transplanting, or post emergence herbicide Bispyribac sodium @ 250 ml/ ha can also be sprayed at 20-25 days after transplanting.",
  
  "Q6": "What are the recommended varieties of direct seeded rice?",
  "A6": "High yielding varieties HPR 1156 (Sukara Dhan), HPR 2656, and HPR 2795.",
  
  "Q7": "When should the first irrigation be applied in direct seeded rice?",
  "A7": "Apply first irrigation at 25 days after sowing and schedule succeeding irrigations as per monsoon rains.",
  
  "Q8": "How can stem borer be managed in rice crop?",
  "A8": "Apply Carbofuran granules (Furadan 3G) @ 33 kg/ ha in standing water after 10 days of transplanting.",
  
  "Q9": "What are the recommended varieties of black gram?",
  "A9": "High yielding varieties UG 218, Him Mash 1, and PB 114 in low and mid hills, and Palampur 93 in high hills (>1500 m amsl).",
  
  "Q10": "What is the recommended herbicide for weed control in kidney bean?",
  "A10": "Pre emergence herbicide Pendimethalin @ 1.5 kg /ha."
}
```

```json
{
  "Q1": "What is unique about the anatomy of millet crops?",
  "A1": "Millet crops have a characteristic Kranz anatomy with C4 pathway that is photosynthetically efficient in utilizing light, water, and CO2.",
  
  "Q2": "What are the advantages of millet crops in terms of growth cycle and stress tolerance?",
  "A2": "Millet crops have a short life cycle, short stature, smaller leaf area, and deeper root systems, making them hardy to stress conditions and able to escape unpredictable late summer droughts.",
  
  "Q3": "How do millet crops tolerate drought stress?",
  "A3": "Millet crops express a set of unique dehydration pathways that can survive under severe drought stress, typically specific to seed desiccation, and have enzymes such as carbonic anhydrase, malate dehydrogenase, and pyruvate orthophosphate dikinase that contribute to their drought tolerance.",
  
  "Q4": "What is the significance of the C4 pathway in millet crops?",
  "A4": "The C4 pathway in millet crops is photosynthetically efficient, resulting in higher biomass and yield, and allows them to operate all C4 subtype pathways, making them powerful model systems for dissecting C4 photosynthesis.",
  
  "Q5": "How do millet crops respond to abiotic stress conditions?",
  "A5": "Millet crops have morpho-physiological and molecular traits such as earliness, small leaf area, waxy leaves, and better leaf venation that contribute to their abiotic stress tolerance, including drought, temperature, and water stress.",
  
  "Q6": "What are the key enzymes involved in the C4 pathway of millet crops?",
  "A6": "The key enzymes involved in the C4 pathway of millet crops include carbonic anhydrase, malate dehydrogenase, malic enzyme, phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase, phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase kinase, and pyruvate orthophosphate dikinase.",
  
  "Q7": "How do millet crops use water efficiently?",
  "A7": "Millet crops have a high water use efficiency due to their C4 cycle and Kranz anatomy, which allows them to operate efficiently under warm temperatures and drought conditions.",
  
  "Q8": "What are the benefits of the short growing season of millet crops?",
  "A8": "The short growing season of millet crops enables them to escape unpredictable late summer droughts and serve as a rescue crop if another grain crop fails.",
  
  "Q9": "What are the functional genes expressed in millet crops under abiotic stress conditions?",
  "A9": "Millet crops express functional genes such as LEA, ARDP, DREB, NAC transcription factor, and others that contribute to their abiotic stress tolerance.",
  
  "Q10": "Why are millet crops considered a model system for studying C4 photosynthesis?",
  "A10": "Millet crops are considered a model system for studying C4 photosynthesis due to their characteristic Kranz anatomy, C4 pathway, and ability to operate all C4 subtype pathways, making them an ideal system for dissecting the mechanisms of C4 photosynthesis."
}
```

```json
{
  "Q1": "What is the recommended method for treating seeds to prevent foot rot?",
  "A1": "Smear the seeds with talc formulation of Trichoderma harzianum @ 15 g per kg of seed immediately before sowing",
  
  "Q2": "When are seedlings of Basmati varieties ready for transplanting?",
  "A2": "When they attain 5 to 6 leaf stage or are 25-30 days old",
  
  "Q3": "What is the recommended spacing for transplanting Basmati seedlings?",
  "A3": "20 x 15 cm (33 hills/sq. metre), but can be reduced to 15x15 cm (44 hills/sq. metre) for late transplanted crop",
  
  "Q4": "Is green manure recommended before planting Basmati?",
  "A4": "Yes, practice green manure before Basmati, and do not apply urea if the field has been green manured with 45-55 days old sunnhemp/dhaincha or summer moong straw",
  
  "Q5": "How should fertilizers be applied for Basmati?",
  "A5": "Apply fertilizers on soil test and crop rotation basis, and skip phosphorus application if the recommended dose of phosphorus has been applied to the preceding wheat crop",
  
  "Q6": "What is the recommended dose of urea for different Basmati varieties?",
  "A6": "45 kg/ha urea for CSR 30, Basamti 386 and Basmati 370, 90 kg/ha urea for varieties like Punjab Basmati 5, 4, 3 & 2 and Pusa Basmati 1121, 1637 & 1718, and 135kg/ha for Pusa Basmati 1509",
  
  "Q7": "How can lodging be checked in Basmati 386 and Basmati 370?",
  "A7": "By lopping of the upper half of crop canopy after 45 days of transplanting, which also reduces stem borer damage",
  
  "Q8": "What is the recommended method for controlling stem borers and leaf folder in Basmati?",
  "A8": "Use 50 g per acre Takumi 20 WG (flubendiamide) for control of stem borers and leaf folder",
  
  "Q9": "What are the recommended Bt cotton varieties for higher yield?",
  "A9": "PAU Bt 3, PAU Bt 2, PAU Bt 1 and other Bt hybrids recommended by PAU, Ludhiana",
  
  "Q10": "What is the recommended method for reducing the adverse effect of salinity in cotton?",
  "A10": "Apply rice-residue biochar 40 q/ha to reduce the adverse effect of salinity and increase yield"
}
```

```json
{
  "Q1": "What are some of the enzymes associated with photosynthetic efficiency in millet crops?",
  "A1": "β-carbonic anhydrase, Glutathione reductase, Dehydroascorbate reductase",
  "Q2": "What is the main difference between C4 and C3 plants in terms of chloroplast structure?",
  "A2": "C4 plants have dimorphic chloroplasts with Kranz anatomy, while C3 plants have monomorphic chloroplasts without Kranz anatomy",
  "Q3": "What are the two types of cells that contain chloroplasts in C4 plants?",
  "A3": "Mesophyll and Bundle Sheath cells",
  "Q4": "What is the CO2 compensation point for C4 plants?",
  "A4": "0-10 ppm",
  "Q5": "What is the temperature optimum for photosynthesis and growth in C4 plants?",
  "A5": "30-45°C",
  "Q6": "How does the Kranz anatomy in C4 plants increase photosynthetic efficiency?",
  "A6": "It increases the concentration of CO2 in the bundle sheath, suppresses photo-respirative loss, and increases the carboxylase activity of RuBisCO",
  "Q7": "What are some of the benefits of C4 photosynthesis over C3 photosynthesis?",
  "A7": "Higher water use efficiency, higher nitrogen use efficiency, improved growth, higher biomass allocation and partitioning, and lower hydraulic conductivity per unit leaf area",
  "Q8": "Why are millets considered a promising option for developing climate-resilient crop species?",
  "A8": "Due to their stress tolerance potential and adaptability to climate change",
  "Q9": "What is needed to fully harness the genetic potential of millet crops?",
  "A9": "High-throughput phenotypic screening, conventional/molecular breeding/transgenic approaches, and technologies",
  "Q10": "What is the potential of millets in terms of sustainable food and nutritional security?",
  "A10": "Millets hold enormous potential for sustainable food and nutritional security due to their underlying physiological characteristics"
}
```

```json
{
```
```json
  "Q1": "Why are millets considered a good crop choice under the threat of climate change?",
  "A1": "Millets are considered a good crop choice under the threat of climate change because they are climate-smart crops that can achieve an assured yield of around 8-10 quintal per acre with low input costs.",
  
  "Q2": "What are the benefits of choosing millets over rice and wheat?",
  "A2": "Choosing millets over rice and wheat can help accomplish the sustainable development goals (SDGs), mainly SDG 2 (zero hunger), SDG 3 (good health and well-being), SDG 12 (sustainable consumption and production), and SDG 13 (climate action).",
  
  "Q3": "What is physiological seed priming and its benefits?",
  "A3": "Physiological seed priming is a technique that fastens the germination time, enhances uniform emergence, seedling vigour, and yields in millets, particularly under rainfed or less fertile soils.",
  
  "Q4": "What are the different types of physiological seed priming techniques?",
  "A4": "The different types of physiological seed priming techniques include hydro-priming, osmo-priming, hormonal priming, nutrient priming, and nano-priming.",
  
  "Q5": "Why are small millets considered nutritionally superior to rice and wheat?",
  "A5": "Small millets are rich in proteins, minerals, and vitamins, making them nutritionally superior to rice and wheat.",
  
  "Q6": "What are the characteristics of small millets that make them resilient to environmental stresses?",
  "A6": "Small millets are inherently resilient to moisture and temperature stress, and can withstand certain degrees of soil acidity and alkalinity.",
  
  "Q7": "Why is uniform and rapid germination important for successful crop establishment?",
  "A7": "Uniform and rapid germination is essential for successful crop establishment, as it optimizes field production of crop plants in arid and semi-arid regions.",
  
  "Q8": "What is the role of seed priming in improving crop production in regions with less rainfall?",
  "A8": "Seed priming can play an important role in improving crop production in regions with less rainfall by enhancing seed germination and seedling emergence.",
  
  "Q9": "What are the critical stages in the plant life cycle where seed priming can make a difference?",
  "A9": "The critical stages in the plant life cycle where seed priming can make a difference are germination and seedling emergence.",
  
  "Q10": "Why is it important for seed producers to maintain seed quality and deliver seeds to farmers at the right time?",
  "A10": "It is important for seed producers to maintain seed quality and deliver seeds to farmers at the right time, as farmers require high-quality seeds with excellent germination and seed health for successful crop establishment."
}
```

{
  "Q1": "What is the recommended time for sowing groundnut in Rajasthan?",

  "A4": "Seed should be treated with 4 ml Chloropyriphos 20 EC/ kg seed kernel before sowing.",
  "Q5": "What is the recommended method for controlling White Grub in groundnut?",
  "A5": "Seed should be treated with 3 ml Imidachloprid 17.8 % SL/ kg seed kernel before sowing.",
  "Q6": "How can Collar Rot & Root Rot be controlled in groundnut?",
  "A6": "Use 4 kg Trichoderma harzianum mixed with 50-60 kg well decomposed FYM, kept in shady place with optimum moisture level for its multiplication and mix in soil in 1 ha area at the time of sowing.",

  "A7": "Paddy nursery can be raised in second fortnight of May",

```json
{
  "Q1": "What are the necessary measures for old orchards?",
  "A1": "Regular irrigation, weeding, and plant protection measures for canker and dieback disease are necessary for old orchards.",
  
  "Q2": "How can canker and dieback disease be prevented and managed?",
  "A2": "Pruning of dried twigs followed by immediate spray of copper oxychloride and two sprays of streptocycline + copper oxychloride at monthly intervals can prevent and manage canker and dieback disease.",
  
  "Q3": "What is the recommended fertilizer application for guava crops?",
  "A3": "For guava crops, 60-70 kg of FYM, 180g of phosphorus, 175g of potassium, and half of the nitrogen (180g) should be applied in June-July, with the remaining nitrogen applied in October and November.",
  
  "Q4": "What are the fertilizer requirements for pomegranate crops in dry areas?",
  "A4": "For pomegranate crops in dry areas, full doses of FYM (40-50 kg), phosphorus (225g), and potassium (200-250g), and half doses of nitrogen (300-350g) should be applied in June, with the second half dose of nitrogen applied after three weeks.",
  
  "Q5": "What are the training and pruning requirements for ber crops?",
  "A5": "For ber crops, training and pruning should be done in early May, followed by application of full dose of organic manure (50-55kg), phosphorus (200g), and potassium (300g), and half dose of nitrogen (250g) in June-July.",
  
  "Q6": "What is the recommended fertilizer application for sapota crops?",
  "A6": "For sapota crops, the full quantity of organic manure (FYM 60 kg) and half doses of chemical fertilizer N:P:K (500: 250: 250 g) should be applied at the beginning of the monsoon, with the second half doses applied in October.",
  
  "Q7": "What are the fertilizer requirements for aonla crops?",
  "A7": "For aonla crops, the whole amount of organic manure (FYM 55-60 kg), phosphatic (P2O5 750g), nitrogen (1500g), and potassium (K2O @ 1000g) should be applied in two split doses, once after fruit set and again during fruit growth and development.",
  
  "Q8": "What is the recommended fertilizer application for date palm crops?",
  "A8": "For date palm crops, FYM @ 10-15 kg should be applied to young plants and 30-40 kg per tree to mature plants in July to September, with urea @ 2.0 kg applied before flowering.",
  
  "Q9": "When should vegetables like early cauliflower and cucurbits be sown?",
  "A9": "The sowing of early cauliflower and cucurbits crops like bottle gourd should be done in the month of June-July.",
  
  "Q10": "What is the importance of monsoon rain in fertilizer application for various crops?",
  "A10": "Monsoon rain plays a crucial role in fertilizer application for various crops, as it helps in the absorption of nutrients by the plants, and many crops require fertilizer application coinciding with monsoon rain."
}
```
